title: Virtual Talk: Chicago Stories
hero_caption: Todros Geller. Strange Worlds, 1928. Gift of Leon Garland Foundation.
short_description: This installment of Chicago Stories, co-facilitated by Art Institute educators Corinne Rose and Nancy Chen, focuses on the artwork of the Ukrainian-born artist Todros Geller as a lens to explore immigrant experience in 1920s Chicago. Through painting and prints, Geller depicted everyday scenes from Jewish immigrant life that reflect the complexities of assimilation and finding a sense of belonging while suspended between old world traditions and modernity in the city of Chicago.
list_description: Educators Corinne Rose and Nancy Chen focus on the artwork of the Ukrainian-born artist Todros Geller as a lens to explore immigrant experience in 1920s Chicago.
description:
This installment of Chicago Stories, co-facilitated by Art Institute educators Corinne Rose and Nancy Chen, focuses on the artwork of the Ukrainian-born artist Todros Geller as a lens to explore immigrant experience in 1920s Chicago. Through painting and prints, Geller depicted everyday scenes from Jewish immigrant life that reflect the complexities of assimilation and finding a sense of belonging while suspended between old world traditions and modernity in the city of Chicago.

In order to allow for conversation and exchange, capacity for this program is limited. Explore all upcoming Virtual Talks.

This virtual event will be hosted on Zoom. Find Zoom tutorials and resources here. If you have any questions about virtual programming, please reach out to museum-programs@artic.edu.
